    Variable Naming System

    variable_naming_system.Rmd

    The variable naming system is a standard approach for classifying allometric response variables and covariates. In the allometric modeling literature, a diverse set of names are often available for many similar types of variables. For example, one may wish to refer to the volume of the main stem of a tree, the volume of the stump, the diameter of a stump, the diameter at breast height, etc.

    The variable naming system, while somewhat verbose and strict, is worth the effort. It allows allometric to efficiently categorize many allometric models in a standardized structure, which facilitates searching and documentation.

    Measures

    All variable names begin with a “measure”, once this measure is established, a decision tree is used to determine the rest of the name. There are [xx] established measures:

    1. d: diameter
    2. h: height
    3. v: volume
    4. g: basal area
    5. b: biomass (weight)
    6. r: ratio (unitless)
    7. e: density

    We recognize that the use of “measure” here is somewhat loose (e.g., diameter and height are both measures of length). However, the variable naming system is meant to preserve at least some connection to commonly used terms for variables in allometric modeling.

    Components

    All variable names then have a second character that specifies the tree component. Established components are:

    1. s: stem (including top and stump)
    2. b: branch
    3. f: foliage
    4. k: bark
    5. c: crown
    6. n: stand - used to refer to stand-level variables (typically used as covariates)
    7. p: plot - used to refer to plot-level variables (typically used as covariates)
    8. u: stump

    Mixing these first two character codes provides an expressive system to refer to measures and components. For example, the biomass of foliage, if one were interested in it, would begin bf, the volume including top and stump of the stem would be va, and the diameter of the stump would be du.

    Measure-Component Modifiers

    Within a given measure-component pair, a number of useful modifiers are available. These are specific to the measure-component pair. For example, an astute modeler may be wondering, “how do I refer to diameter at breast height outside bark”? These modifiers enable this level of specificity.

    Diameter of Stem (ds) Modifiers

    Some of the most common allometric variables are that of stem diameter, which arises in taper modeling, merchantable heights and, of course, diameter at breast height. ds modifiers enable a user to specify these broad range of variables.

    ds modifiers are broken down into two parts. The first character is the bark modifier and the second character is the height modifier. The bark modifiers are:

    • o: outside bark
    • i: inside bark

    and the height modifiers are:

    • b: breast height
    • s: stump height
    • m: merchantable height
    • [##]: specified height, using p as a decimal point if necessary.

    For example, diameter (of the stem) at breast height outside bark is dsob and dso40 is diameter (of the stem) outside bark at 40 units of length along the stem.

    Height of Stem (hs) Modifiers

    • t: total (base to tip)
    • b: crown base (base to crown base)
    • m: merchantable diameter
    • s: stump (base to stump)

    Volume of Stem (vs) Modifiers

    -[write later]
